informal_statement: Suppose that $h(x)=f^{-1}(x)$. If $h(2)=10$, $h(10)=1$ and $h(1)=2$, what is $f(f(10))$? Show that it is 1.
informal_proof: Since $f$ and $h$ are inverse functions and $h(2) = 10$, $f(10) = 2$, so $f(f(10)) = f(2)$.  And since $h(1) = 2$, $f(2) = 1$.
formal_statement:
theorem mathd_algebra_209:
  fixes \<sigma>::"real \<Rightarrow> real"
  assumes "bij \<sigma>"
    and "(Hilbert_Choice.inv \<sigma>) 2 = 10"
    and "(Hilbert_Choice.inv \<sigma>) 10 = 1"
    and "(Hilbert_Choice.inv \<sigma>) 1 = 2" 
  shows "\<sigma> (\<sigma> 10) = 1"
formal_code:
(*
  Authors: Wenda Li
*)

theory mathd_algebra_209 imports Complex_Main
begin

theorem mathd_algebra_209:
  fixes \<sigma>::"real \<Rightarrow> real"
  assumes "bij \<sigma>"
    and "(Hilbert_Choice.inv \<sigma>) 2 = 10"
    and "(Hilbert_Choice.inv \<sigma>) 10 = 1"
    and "(Hilbert_Choice.inv \<sigma>) 1 = 2" 
  shows "\<sigma> (\<sigma> 10) = 1"
  by (metis assms(1) assms(2) assms(4) bij_inv_eq_iff)

end
